We used the BASE-future and PHYS-future simulations of the change in the global dust emission rate to obtain κ. Specifically, we use the global emission rate as a proxy for the global dust loading, such that we approximated κ as the relative change in dust loading (Δ Q/ Q 0) per degree surface temperature change (Δ T), which we obtained from the linear least-squares fits of Δ Q/ Q 0 to Δ T (Fig. 3). We use this assumption because previous model simulations have indicated that the modeled dust lifetime, which determines how the emission rate is converted to loading, is relatively insensitive to climate
6 . Furthermore, uncertainties in other components of the estimation of κ and λ dust, such as due to uncertainties in future precipitation change and the dust DRE, are quite large, such that uncertainties due to possible changes in dust lifetime is likely to be a small contributor to the uncertainty in κ.
